{{DEFAULTSORT:Beveridge, Henry}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Scottish orientalists]] [[Category:Scottish atheists]] [[Category:Scottish humanists]] [[Category:Indian Civil Service (British India) officers]] [[Category:British Indologists]] [[Category:British translators]] [[Category:Translators from Persian]] [[Category:Social reformers]] [[Category:Presidents of The Asiatic Society]]

{{refimprove |date=October 2017}} The '''Hingorja''' are a [[Muslim]] community found in the state of a province of [[Sindh]] in [[Pakistan]]. They are one of a number of communities of pastoral nomads found in the [[Banni Grasslands Reserve|Banni]] region of [[Kutch]].<ref>People of India Gujarat Volume XXI Part Two edited by R.B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan & M Azeez Mohideen pages 509-512</ref>
==History and origin==
The Hingorja claim descent from [[Samma (tribe)|Samma]] [[Rajput]]s, who were devotees of Hinglaj Mata, whose temple is situated in [[Hingol]] in [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Baluchistan]]. They were converted to [[Islam]], about five centuries ago, and migrated to [[Kutch]] in search of pasture. The Hingorja perceive themselves to be [[Muslim Rajput]]s.<ref>People of India Gujarat Volume XXI Part Two edited by R.B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan & M Azeez Mohideen pages 509-512</ref>
==Present circumstances==
The community is concentrated in the villages of Nandi Daddar, Mota Banda and Dumcara in the [[talukas|taluka]] of [[Bhuj]], in the [[Kutch District]] of [[Gujarat]], and the neighbouring districts of [[Badin District|Badin]] and [[Tharparkar District|Tharparkar]] in [[Sindh]]. They speak a dialect of [[Kutchi language|Kutchi]], with substantial [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] loan words. The community is endogamous, but does marry with other [[Samma (tribe)|Samma]] communities, such as the [[Hingora]]. They are divided into a number of clans, the main ones being the Malwani, Jeshwani, Parian, Rebani and Kheera.<ref>People of India Gujarat Volume XXI Part Two edited by R.B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan & M Azeez Mohideen pages 509-512</ref>
The Hingorja are a community of [[Maldhari]] cattle breeders. In addition to cattle breeding, the Hingorja are also cultivators, and landless agricultural labourers. Like other [[Kutchi people|Kutchi]] communities, many of them have migrated to other parts of [[India]] in search of employment.<ref>People of India Gujarat Volume XXI Part Two edited by R.B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan & M Azeez Mohideen pages 509-512</ref>
==See also== *[[Hingora]] *[[Samma (tribe)|Samma]] *[[Sindhi Rajput]]s
==References==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Social groups of Gujarat]] [[Category:Tribes of Kutch]] [[Category:Maldhari communities]] [[Category:Muslim communities of India]] [[Category:Sindhi tribes]] [[Category:Samma tribes|*]] [[Category:Sindhi tribes in India]] [[Category:Muslim communities of Gujarat]]

{{short description|Idea that comparative uses of the word Holocaust trivialize the Holocaust}} {{see also|Holocaust denial}} Many authors argue that a metaphorical (or otherwise comparative) use of the word ''[[Holocaust]]'' constitutes '''Holocaust trivialization''', and many consider such uses offensive.''[http://www.bnaibrith.ca/publications/audit2000/audit2000-03.html Antisemitism and Hate in Canada]'', from the League for Human Rights of Canada In the words of Holocaust survivor and memoirist [[Elie Wiesel]],
I cannot use [the word 'Holocaust'] anymore. First, because there are no words, and also because it has become so trivialized that I cannot use it anymore. Whatever mishap occurs now, they call it 'holocaust'. I have seen it myself in television in the country in which I live. A commentator describing the defeat of a sports team, somewhere, called it a 'holocaust'. I have read in a very prestigious newspaper published in California, a description of the murder of six people, and the author called it a holocaust. So, I have no words anymore.''Comprehending the Holocaust: Historical and Literary Research'', ed. Asher Cohen, Joav Gelber, and Charlotte Wardi.
[[Manfred Gerstenfeld]] identifies trivialization and universalization of the Holocaust as one of eleven forms of Holocaust distortion. Holocaust trivialization involves the application of language that is specific to describing the Holocaust to events and purposes that are unrelated to it.{{cite web|last=Gerstenfeld|first=Manfred|title=The Multiple Distortions of Holocaust Memory|url=http://jcpa.org/article/the-multiple-distortions-of-holocaust-memory/|publisher=[[Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs]]|accessdate=31 May 2012|authorlink=Manfred Gerstenfeld|date=28 October 2007}} On the other hand, [[David Stannard]] argued that attempts to eliminate Holocaust comparisons belittle other events of comparable magnitude.Stannard, David E. [http://chronicle.com/che-data/articles.dir/art-42.dir/issue-47.dir/47b00101.htm "The dangers of calling the Holocaust unique"], ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'', August 2, 1996. == Notable cases == The [[Anti-Defamation League]] has accused [[Gilad Atzmon]] of trivializing and distorting the Holocaust specifically in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The ADL states that, among other abuses, Atzmon invoked the word ''[[Shoah]]'' to describe Israel's treatment of the Palestinians.{{cite web|title=Backgrounder: Gilad Atzmon|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Anti_Semitism_International/gilad-atzmon-anti-semite.htm|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]|access-date=31 May 2012|date=30 January 2012}} The Center for Israel and Jewish Affairs condemned the [[United Church of Canada]] for trivializing the Holocaust. According to the Center, the United Church published a document{{Cite web |title=Government Advocacy Around Palestine and Israel |url=https://www.united-church.ca/social-action/justice-initiatives/government-advocacy-around-palestine-and-israel |publisher=The [[United Church of Canada]] |access-date=11 July 2018}}{{Cite conference |title=The Working Group on Israel/Palestine Policy (2012) |url=https://commons.united-church.ca/Documents/What%20We%20Believe%20and%20Why/Peace/Working%20Group%20on%20Palestine%20Israel%20Policy.docx |conference=41st General Council (2012) |date=1 August 2012 |format=[[DOCX]] (Microsoft Word) |publisher=The [[United Church of Canada]] |access-date=11 July 2018}} in which they placed a statement decrying the "loss of dignity" on the part of the Palestinians, attributed to Israel, promptly after a similar statement acknowledging "the denial of human dignity to Jews" in the Holocaust.{{cite news|last=Lungen|first=Paul|title=CIJA slams United Church stance on Mideast|url=http://www.cjnews.com/canada/cija-slams-united-church-stance-mideast|access-date=31 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Canadian Jewish News]]|date=7 May 2012}} == See also == * [[Holocaust (disambiguation)]] lists a number of events dubbed "Holocaust" * [[Survivors of the Abortion Holocaust]] * ''[[Is the Holocaust Unique?]]'' * ''[[The Holocaust Industry]]'' == References == '''Notes''' {{reflist}} '''Further reading''' * [[Manfred Gerstenfeld|Gerstenfeld, Manfred]] [http://jcpa.org/article/holocaust-trivialization/ "Holocaust Trivialization"], [[Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs]] * Katz, Steven (1994) ''The Holocaust in Historical Context'' Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{isbn|9780195072204}} * Shafir, Michael (2002) "Between Denial and 'Comparative Trivialization' – Holocaust Negationism in Post-Communist East Central Europe", ''Acta – Analysis of Current Trends in Antisemitism'', n.19 p.23, Jerusalem: [[Hebrew University]], [[Vidal Sassoon International Center for the Study of Antisemitism]] * Sullam Calimani, Anna-Vera (October 1999) [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3737232?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents "A Name for Extermination"] ''[[The Modern Language Review]] v.94 n.4 pp.978-99. DOI: 10.2307/3737232 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holocaust Trivialization Debate}} [[Category:Holocaust historiography|Trivialization]] [[Category:Political science terminology]] [[Category:Controversies]] [[Category:Holocaust denial]]

page.title: International Association of Independent Journalists Inc.

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:International organisations based in Canada]] to [[Category:International organizations based in Canada]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = International Association of Independent Journalists Inc. |image = LogoIAIJ.jpg |image_border = |size = |caption = IAIJ Logo | type = [[Non-profit organization|Non-profit]] | founded_date = 2003
[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] | founder = Maurice Ali | location = {{flagicon|CAN}}[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada
{{flagicon|ENG}}[[London]], [[England]]
(International) | key_people = | area_served = Worldwide | focus = [[Journalism]] | method = [[lobbying]], [[research]] | revenue = | num_members = | motto = Journalists in action around the world! | homepage = {{URL|www.iaij.org}} }} The '''International Association of Independent Journalists Inc.''' ('''IAIJ''') is a registered not-for-profit journalist association with offices in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada and [[London]], England. The association is international and caters to amateur (citizen journalists) and professional journalists with advocacy and support services worldwide. ==History== The International Association of Independent Journalists was created in October 2003 by Maurice Ali who was a journalist and writer living in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. In his book "Protest!: The Fall of Civil Disobedience,"{{cite news|last=|first=|title='Protest!: The Fall Of Civil Disobedience'|pages=|publisher=Fortress Of Freedom Inc.|year= 2004|url=http://amicus.collectionscanada.gc.ca/aaweb-bin/aamain/itemdisp?sessionKey=999999999_142&l=0&lvl=1&v=1&itm=31463160&rt=1&bill=1|accessdate=22 August 2011}} {{ISBN|0-9736335-0-6}} (Pages 195-207). Maurice Ali noted the emergence of the "citizen journalist" and that the journalist community should be more inclusive of all types of journalists, and this same sentiment became the basis for IAIJ's constitution when incorporated as a not-for-profit corporation on February 12, 2008 (Letters Patent file number: 446727-2).{{cite news|last=|first=|title='Corporations Canada'|pages=|publisher=Government Of Canada|date=February 12, 2008|url=https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=4467272&V_TOKEN=1489942541889&crpNm=International|accessdate=19 March 2017}} This constitution of inclusion followed most closely, the policies and mandates of the U.N./UNESCO derived from Article 19 of the United Nation's [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]]. The association grew over the years, gained a second office in London, England; and on June 11, 2011 the association became an "Institutional Member" of the Canadian Commission for UNESCO which is located in [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada. On July 25, 2016 IAIJ attained Consultative Status at the United Nations. ==Operations== Membership of the association is in the hundreds with a Board of Directors. A general meeting is held each year at the head office in Toronto on February 12. Membership is international and support and services are dispatched through offices in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, and London, England. The association has a diploma program for self-improvement and also provides editorial material for a newspaper called "The Fortress."{{cite news|last=|first=|title='The Fortress|pages=|publisher=Fortress Of Freedom Inc.|date=April 2004|url=http://amicus.collectionscanada.gc.ca/aaweb-bin/aamain/itemdisp?sessionKey=999999999_142&l=0&d=2&v=0&lvl=1&itm=38649757|accessdate=22 August 2011}} ISSN 1923-9858. ==Advocacy== The association through its President (Maurice Ali) and the membership have participated in advocacy by published studies and articles on citizen journalism, attended and spoken at UNESCO{{cite news|last=|first=|title='Citizen Journalism’ |pages=|publisher=UNESCO |date=February 27, 2013|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/CI/CI/pdf/news/30_citizen_journalism.pdf|accessdate=2 August 2011}} and United Nations events{{cite news|last=|first=|title='WSIS+10 United Nations General Assembly High-Level Meeting’ |pages=|publisher=United Nations |date=July 2, 2015|url=https://publicadministration.un.org/wsis10/2julystakeholderconsultation|accessdate=2 August 2016}}{{cite news|last=|first=|title='Maurice Ali Speech: International Association of Independent Journalists Inc. WSIS+10-United Nations-July 2, 2015' |pages=|publisher=United Nations |date=July 2, 2015|url=http://workspace.unpan.org/sites/Internet/Documents/UNPAN94870.pdf|accessdate=2 August 2016}} as advocates of citizen journalism worldwide. ==Awards== The International Association of Independent Journalists Inc. has an award called the "IAIJ Award for Journalism" and is presented to journalists who have distinguished themselves in news gathering and investigative reporting. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|www.iaij.org}} [[Category:International organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Canadian journalism organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2003]] [[Category:Citizen journalism]] [[Category:Online journalism]]

Some [[association football]] players are [[Muslims]], and their clubs have adapted to their principles.
In July 2013, [[BBC]] journalist Rob Cowling remarked that Muslim players were changing the culture of English football.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23159023|title=Premier League: How Muslims are changing English football culture|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=10 July 2013|author=Rob Cowling|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The Islamic observance of [[Ramadan]], affects the ability of players to train and play,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/fasting-and-football-how-do-topflight-muslims-cope-2342187.html|title=Fasting and football. How do top-flight Muslims cope?|date=23 August 2011|accessdate=10 July 2013|author=Tusdiq Din|publisher=The Independent}}</ref> while some players have refused to wear football shirts sponsored by gambling and finance companies, as [[Maisir|gambling]] and [[Riba|charging interest]] are forbidden in Islam.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22857014|title=Newcastle's Papiss Cisse plans club talks over new shirt sponsor|date=12 June 2013|accessdate=10 July 2013|author=Saj Chowdhury and Ben Smith|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
Some Muslim players have been subjected to [[racism in association football|racist abuse in the sport]], and clubs which sign Muslim players have also been targeted.<ref name=Beitar>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/08/world/meast/israel-football-arson|title=Israeli football club torched after signing Muslim players|date=8 February 2013|accessdate=10 July 2013|author=Paul Gittings|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
==Popularity and conflict== Football was introduced to Iran by British oil workers and promoted under the regime of [[Reza Shah]] in the 1920s. Although both playing and watching the game have often been in conflict with religious requirements under the [[Islamic Republic of Iran]], it continues to be popular.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.payvand.com/news/13/jun/1037.html | title=Iran in June: A Fever Pitch of Football and Politics | publisher=www.payvand.com | date=5 June 2013 | accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref>
[[Football in the Palestinian territories|Football in Palestine]] was introduced during the [[Mandatory Palestine|British mandate]] period of 1920-1948. In 2011 a women's football team called Girls FC, made-up of both Muslims and Christians, was formed. Despite [[Intimate parts in Islam|religious requirements]] and objections at the women wearing shorts and "playing a man's game", the team proved to be popular.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/aljazeeraworld/2012/06/2012626105337593602.html | title=Girls FC | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=27 June 2012 | accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref>
==Football and Ramadan== In 2010 Iranian player [[Ali Karimi]] was sacked by his [[Tehran]]-based club [[Steel Azin]] for breaking the fast during Ramadan. Karimi was seen drinking water during a training session; he denied any insult and was reinstated by the club after agreeing to pay a $40,000 fine.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11095904 | title=Iran footballer returns after Ramadan fasting row | publisher=BBC News Middle East | date=26 August 2010 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Adams, Keith}}</ref> In 2011 the debilitating effect on the fitness of players was noted in connection with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] player [[Demba Ba]]. Described as "drained and lethargic" due to [[Sawn of Ramadan|fasting during Ramadan]], he scored three goals in just over thirty minutes in a 3-1 win against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in his first match after Ramadan.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/newcastle-united/8788187/Newcastle-Uniteds-Demba-Bas-destroys-Blackburn-Rovers-with-a-hat-trick.html | title=Newcastle United's Demba Ba's destroys Blackburn Rovers with a hat-trick | publisher=Daily Telegraph | date=25 September 2011 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Edwards, Luke}}</ref>
==Football and Islamic prayer== [[File:Cheikhou Kouyaté makes dua.jpg|thumb|80px|[[Cheikhou Kouyaté]] makes [[dua]] before a game]] Observance of their Islamic prayers has brought players into conflict with their managers. [[Harry Redknapp]], when manager of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], was critical of player [[Frédéric Kanouté]]'s prayer and fasting requirements.<ref name="BaconBlows2012">{{cite book|author1=Steve Bacon|author2=Kirk Blows|title=There's Only One Stevie Bacon: My Life Watching West Ham Through a Camera Lens|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c_atAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA1894|date=16 August 2012|publisher=Biteback Publishing|isbn=978-1-84954-459-7|pages=1894–}}</ref> Newcastle United considered the introduction of prayer rooms at both [[St James' Park]] and at their training ground. Whilst not designed exclusively for Muslims, the rooms were planned to be used for [[salat|prayer]] by Muslim players Demba Ba, [[Papiss Cissé]], [[Hatem Ben Arfa]] and [[Cheik Tioté]]. The club pointed out that this is in marked contrast to the experiences of their former player and convert to Islam, [[Didier Domi]], who was mocked when discovered doing Islamic prayers in the showers.<ref name="Domi">{{cite web | url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Articles/Dossier/ARTJAJA2562p024-033.xml4/france-musulman-islam-bruno-metsuvivre-sa-foi-au-grand-jour.html | title=Islam made in France | publisher=www.jeuneafrique.com | date=23 February 2010 | accessdate=2 November 2013 | author=Ghozali, Faïza | language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/may/05/alan-pardew-newcastle-united-manchester-city | title=Alan Pardew keeping the faith in the Newcastle United revolution | publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' | date=5 May 2012 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Taylor, Louise}}</ref> By the [[2012-13 Newcastle United F.C. season|2012-13 season]] Newcastle's seven Muslim players regularly used a purpose built multi-faith [[Darsley Park|training ground]] prayer room.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2013/jun/17/newcastle-united-joe-kinnear-alan-pardew | title=Joe Kinnear's second coming could cause Newcastle United further regret | publisher=The Guardian | date=17 June 2013 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Taylor, Louise}}</ref>
Several players, such as Demba Ba and Papiss Cissé, choose an act of [[Sujud|prostration]] with forehead to the ground as a celebration after scoring a goal.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/demba-ba-interview-chelsea-is-the-start-of-my-career-8581069.html | title=Demba Ba interview: 'Chelsea is the start of my career' | publisher=The Independent | date=20 April 2013 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Wallace, Sam}}</ref> In 2012 football commentator [[Gary Lineker]] was forced to apologise after describing one such celebration by player [[Karim Ait-Fana]] for French side [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]] against [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke]] in the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] as "eating grass".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/gary-lineker-apologises-after-joking-that-praying-muslim-footballers-were-eating-grass-8202728.html | title=Gary Lineker apologises after joking that praying Muslim footballers were 'eating grass' | publisher=The Independent | date=8 October 2012 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Hall, John}}</ref> Muslim footballers have also worn T-shirts carrying messages relating to Islam under their football shirts. [[Queen's Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] player [[Adel Taarabt]] has worn a shirt carrying the message "I Love Allah" whilst [[Samir Nasri]], in 2012, celebrated a goal for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] with a shirt carrying the message "[[Eid Mubarak]]".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://islamiquemagazine.com/the-influence-of-islam-on-english-football/ | title=The Influence Of Islam On English Football | publisher=Islamique Magazine | accessdate=12 July 2013 | author=Aleem, Abdul}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2012-08-19/nasri-celebrates-winning-goal-against-southampton-with-eid-mubarak-t-shirt/ | title=Nasri celebrates goal against Southampton with 'Eid Mubarak' T-shirt | publisher=ITV | date=19 August 2012 | accessdate=12 July 2013}}</ref>
In October 2016, fans attending a World Cup qualifying game between [[Iran national football team|Iran]] and [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] at the [[Azadi Stadium]] in [[Tehran]] were asked to replace usual football chanting with religious chants as the match fell on a day of commemoration for [[Tasu'a]], a [[Shia Islam]] holy day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37616279|title=Iran v South Korea: Supporters asked to mourn at World Cup qualifier|date=11 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=11 October 2016|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==Islam and football shirts==
Muslim leaders in [[Malaysia]] have called for Muslims not to wear football shirts with [[crucifix|crosses]] on the badge, such as [[FC Barcelona]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], seeing them as prioritising [[Christianity]]. They have also warned against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] shirts, which feature a [[devil]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/malaysia/7900366/Muslims-ban-Manchester-United-shirts-over-red-devil-image.html | title=Muslims ban Manchester United shirts over red devil image | publisher=The Telegraph | date=20 July 2010 | accessdate=11 July 2013 | author=Henderson, Barney}}</ref>
In 2012 [[Real Madrid CF|Real Madrid]] removed a cross from their [[Real Madrid CF#Crest and shirt|club crest]] on promotional material.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/soccer-dirty-tackle/real-madrid-small-distinct-change-crest-uae-resort-202900831.html | title=Real Madrid make small but deliberate change to their crest for UAE resort island partnership | publisher=Sports.Yahoo.com | date=30 March 2012 | accessdate=18 October 2013 | author=Peck, Brooks}}</ref> The change was linked with the building of a $1 billion [[Real Madrid Resort Island|sports tourist resort]] in the Islamic [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianmuslimobserver.com/2012/04/real-madrid-changing-cross-logo-for.html |title=Real Madrid changing cross logo for Muslim fans, sponsors |publisher=Indian Muslim Observer |date=13 April 2013 |accessdate=12 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928034541/http://www.indianmuslimobserver.com/2012/04/real-madrid-changing-cross-logo-for.html |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theeasternpost.org/show_news.php?ofPage=16&id=3189&headLine=Real-Madrid-Reband-Logo-for-Muslim-Fans | title=Real Madrid Reband Logo for Muslim Fans | publisher=The Eastern Post | accessdate=12 July 2013}}</ref>
[[Frédéric Kanouté]] used to modify his [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] shirt, to obscure the sponsorship from online casino [[888.com]]. The club later came to an agreement that the player was not endorsing gambling by wearing it, and would be excused from any promotional material with 888.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/apr/05/newsstory.sport|title=Where did it all go right for Fredi Kanouté?|first=Ben|last=Clissitt|date=5 April 2007|publisher=|accessdate=11 October 2016|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
In July 2013 Newcastle United player [[Papiss Cissé]] refused to play in a shirt sponsored by [[Wonga.com]], a [[payday loan]] company, as the charging of interest is not permitted under [[Fiqh|Islamic law]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23347131 | title=Papiss Cisse pulls out of Newcastle tour after sponsor row | publisher=BBC Sport | date=17 July 2013 | accessdate=18 July 2013 | author=Smith, Ben}}</ref> Soon after, he agreed to wear the shirt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jul/25/papiss-cisse-newcastle-wonga-row|title=Papiss Cissé stands down in Wonga row and agrees to wear branded kit|first=Louise|last=Taylor|date=25 July 2013|publisher=|accessdate=11 October 2016|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
==Islamic dress code and football== The requirements of Islamic dress code have been contradictory to the kit requirements of [[FIFA]]. In 2011 the [[Iran women's national football team|Iran women's football team]] was prevented from playing a game in a qualifying round for the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics - Women's tournament|2012 Olympic Games]] due to their kit which comprised full tracksuits and head coverings concealing their hair. Women in Iran are required to wear the [[Hijab by country#Iran|maghnaeh]] to cover their heads. FIFA ruled that the kit broke one of their rules which states, "''Players and officials shall not display political, religious, commercial or personal messages or slogans in any language or form on their playing or team kits''." Although the Iranian footballing federation argued that the kit was neither religious nor political, Iran were prevented from playing the game which was awarded, 3-0 to [[Jordan women's national football team|Jordan]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jun/06/iran-women-olympic-strip | title=Iran's women footballers banned from Olympics because of Islamic strip | publisher=The Guardian | date=6 June 2011 | accessdate=12 July 2013}}</ref> By 2012 FIFA had changed their ruling declaring that women were free to wear the hijab at senior competitive level.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/sports/summer/football/17585-joy-for-fifa-prince-as-football-hijab-ban-is-lifted | title=Joy for FIFA Prince and Muslim women as football hijab ban is lifted | publisher=www.insidethegames.biz | date=5 July 2012 | accessdate=12 July 2013 | author=Warshaw, Andrew}}</ref>
==Abuse==
There have been numerous cases of [[Islamophobia|anti-Muslim abuse]] aimed at Muslim footballers. In 2005 Egyptian footballer [[Mido (footballer)|Mido]] whilst playing for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hostpur]] was taunted by fans of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] with "''Your mum's a terrorist''" and as a shoe bomber due to his likeness to [[Richard Reid]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/nov/26/sport.comment3 | title=Mido: I love it here and I want to stay | publisher=The Guardian | date=26 November 2005 | accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref> In 2007, Mido, then playing for [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] was taunted by [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] fans with anti-Muslim abuse.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/aug/28/newsstory.middlesbrough | title=FA to investigate anti-Muslim abuse aimed at Mido | publisher=The Guardian | date=28 August 2007 | accessdate=15 July 2013 | author=Taylor, Louise}}</ref>
In October 2013 Muslim supporters of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] were verbally abused whilst conducting [[Maghrib prayer]] in the [[Boleyn Ground]] during a [[Premier League]] game between West Ham and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01k8bjk | title=Muslims face racist chants at West Ham | publisher=BBC News | date=24 October 2013 | accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref> In March 2015, Muslim supporters of [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] were criticised and abused on social media after they had used the half-time interval to pray on prayer mats in a stairwell at [[Anfield]] during a match between Liverpool and [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]. Their prayers were also defended by other fans.<ref name="PrayerTweet">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-32326228 | title=Liverpool FC considers action over Muslim prayer tweet | publisher=BBC News | date=15 April 2015 | accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>
Israeli club [[Beitar Jerusalem]] had their offices burned by Jewish nationalists in January 2013 after signing their first Muslim players.<ref name=Beitar/>
==In film== The 2006 film ''[[Offside (2006 Iranian film)|Offside]]'' deals with the subject of football, in this case in Iran, and female spectators. A ban made during the [[1979 Iranian Revolution]] which stopped women from attending games, with Islamic religious leaders stating that women in stadiums was a recipe for disaster as they would see "bare legs" and hear profanities shouted by male fans. President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] had tried to end the ban before his attempts were vetoed by the country's supreme leader, [[Ayatollah Ali Khamenei]]. The film tells the stories of girls disguising themselves as males in order to watch a [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|qualification]] match between [[Iran national football team|Iran]] and [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] at the [[Azadi Stadium]] in [[Tehran]]. It was banned from screening in Iran.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2006/05/20084913126165646.html | title=Iran censors hand Offside a red card | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=23 May 2006 | accessdate=12 July 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Christianity and association football]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Association football culture]] [[Category:Association football issues]] [[Category:History of association football]] [[Category:Islam and sport]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{Other uses|Knickerbocker (disambiguation){{!}}Knickerbocker}} {{coord|40.829138|-73.701659|format=dms|display=title}} {{Infobox organization | name = Knickerbocker Yacht Club | bgcolor = <!-- header background color --> | fgcolor = <!-- header text color --> | image = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = 1874 | extinction = 2009 | type = [[Yacht club]] | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = to encourage "Yachting and the cultivation of Naval Science and Seamanship" | headquarters = | location = [[Port Washington, New York|Port Washington]], New York | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = | membership = | language = <!-- official languages --> | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = <!-- position title for the leader of the org --> | leader_name = <!-- name of leader --> | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = *[[Lon Myers]], world-record-holding runner *[[Bus Mosbacher]], skippered two winning teams in America's Cup races *[[Robert Mosbacher]], world champion sailor | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = | remarks = | former name = }} The '''Knickerbocker Yacht Club''' was a [[yacht club]] in [[Port Washington, New York|Port Washington]], New York.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news|author=Peter Applebome |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/12/nyregion/12towns.html |title=The Recession Takes Down a Yacht Club |location=Long Island Sound |work=The New York Times |date=February 11, 2009 |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref>
The club was founded in 1874, on the [[Harlem River]] at 130th Street in Manhattan, to encourage “Yachting and the cultivation of Naval Science and Seamanship”.<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fMIWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA147&dq=%22Knickerbocker+Yacht+Club%22+1874&hl=en&ei=8KapTrDNN8jx0gHw3tn3DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Knickerbocker%20Yacht%20Club%22%201874&f=false |title=Brooklyn daily eagle almanac |publisher=Brooklyn Daily Eagle |year=1901|author= |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref><ref name="antonnews2007">{{cite news|url=http://www.antonnews.com/portwashingtonnews/2007/02/23/news/nautical.html |title=Port's Nautical History Exhibit in Port Library |publisher=Antonnews.com |date=February 23, 2007 |author=Bob Hogan |accessdate=October 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403024751/http://www.antonnews.com/portwashingtonnews/2007/02/23/news/nautical.html |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In 1907, it moved to Port Washington. It started the Knickerbocker Cup race in 1982, which became internationally recognized.<ref name="antonnews2007"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/24/nyregion/long-island-journal-929495.html |title=LONG ISLAND JOURNAL |work=The New York Times |date=September 24, 1995 |author=Diane Ketcham |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref>
At its peak in the early 1980s, membership consisted of approximately 290 families with 165 boats.<ref name="nytimes1"/>
World champion runner [[Lon Myers]] began his track career running for the club.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7a5MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA55&dq=%22Knickerbocker+Yacht+Club%22+lon+myers&hl=en&ei=SKupTsfBB8fh0QGCh5j1DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Knickerbocker%20Yacht%20Club%22%20lon%20myers&f=false |title=A history of American amateur athletics and aquatics: with the records|author=Frederick William Janssen |publisher=Outing Co. |year= 1888|accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JSH/JSH1975/JSH0202/jsh0202b.pdf|title=L. E. Myers, "World’s Greatest Runner"|publisher=Journal of Sport History |year= 1975|author=Joe D. Willis and Richard G. Wettan|accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref> [[Bus Mosbacher]], who skippered two winning teams in the America's Cup races, and world champion sailor [[Robert Mosbacher]] were members of the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/14/nyregion/emil-mosbacher-dies-at-75-yachtsman-and-nixon-official.html |title=Emil Mosbacher Dies at 75; Yachtsman and Nixon Official |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 14, 1997 |author= |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1939/08/18/archives/mosbachers-crew-wins-junior-title-takes-sound-sailing-cup-for.html |title=MOSBACHER'S CREW WINS JUNIOR TITLE; Takes Sound Sailing Cup for Knickerbocker by Point, With Black Rock Next Pequot Unlucky Defender Causes Wind Trouble |publisher= The New York Times|date=August 18, 1939 |author= |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/csmonitor_historic/access/282317812.html?dids=282317812:282317812&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Aug+21%2C+1940&author=&pub=Christian+Science+Monitor&desc=Mosbacher+Takes+Three+Firsts+To+Win+Midget+Title&pqatl=google |title=Mosbacher Takes Three Firsts To Win Midget Title |publisher=The Christian Science Monitor |date=August 21, 1940 |author= |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref>
As of 2009, it was the second-oldest yacht club on [[Long Island Sound]].<ref name="nytimes1"/> Due to the recession and waning membership, the club ceased to exist in 2009 and was sold for $3.2 million to Cord Meyer Development. In July 2012 demolition of the club began, the developers began on a new structure which today is the Knickerbocker Yacht Hotel designed to evoke a cruise ship. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/29/realestate/long-island-in-the-region-bon-voyage-to-a-gilded-club.html |title=Bon Voyage to a Gilded Club |publisher=New York Times |date=July 26, 2012 |author= |accessdate=June 17, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=XuEuGwAACAAJ&dq=%22Knickerbocker+Yacht+Club%22+1874&hl=en&ei=8KapTrDNN8jx0gHw3tn3DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA ''The Knickerbocker Yacht Club: seventy-fifth anniversary, 1874-1949''], Knickerbocker Yacht Club

page.title: Kreeta Haapasalo Playing the Kantele in a Peasant Cottage

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2017}}
{{Infobox artwork | title = Kreeta Haapasalo Playing the Kantele in a Peasant Cottage | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = Finnish | other_title_1 = Kreeta Haapasalo soittaa kannelta talonpoikaistuvassa | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image = Robert_Wilhelm_Ekman_-_Kreeta_Haapasalo_Playing_the_Kantele_in_a_Peasant_Cottage.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | artist = Robert Wilhelm Ekman | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1868}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | medium = oil on canvas | material = | subject = | height_metric = 75 <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = 105 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = [[Helsinki]] | museum = [[Ateneum]] | accession = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = [[Finnish National Gallery]] | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Kreeta Haapasalo Playing the Kantele in a Peasant Cottage ''''' is an oil work on canvas painted in 1868 by [[Robert Wilhelm Ekman]] (1808-1873).
== Description == The dimensions of the painting are 75 × 105 cm. It was purchased for the collection of the [[Ateneum]] in 1869.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/2063618/FI_280_001.html|title=Kreeta Haapasalo Playing the Kantele in a Peasant Cottage|website=www.europeana.eu|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref>
A number of people listen to a [[kantele]] playing. This includes the mistress of the house, young women and their children. Leaning in the corner is a pipe-smoking soldier. The environment is simple, related to their everyday chores, and lit by a daylit window. The work reflects an idealized vision of the Finnish nation and its values.
== Analysis == [[Kreeta Haapasalo]] was a well-known folk musician who in periods of famine in the 1860s fed a family by traveling as a [[kantele]] player, singing poetry. It brought her great popularity at a time of great interest in the roots of the Finnish people. Haapasalo was seen at the time as part of an ancient tradition as an interpreter of the [[Kalevala]], through which she was able to get in touch with genuine Finnish culture.
Robert Ekman, the painter, was interested in the origins of Finnish culture. Ekman studied at the Stockholm Academy of Art. He was interested in historical development and the public life of the Finnish people. His genre paintings depicting it were well received. He returned to Finland on a permanent basis, after an Italian and French tour in 1845, after which he taught until his death in [[Turku]] drawing school, which he established in the following year.
== References == <references />
== Sources == * Anja Olavinen: Robert Wilhelm Ekman: Kreeta Haapasalo soittaa kannelta talonpoikaistuvassa. Teoksessa Ateneum-opas. Toim. Timo Huusko. 2007, s. 17.
== External links == * [http://kokoelmat.fng.fi/app?action=page&lang=fi&si=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.muusa.net%2FE42_Object_Identifier%2FA_I_42 Teos Suomen Kansallisgallerian kokoelmissa: Kreeta Haapasalo soittaa kannalta talonpoikaistuvassa.] * [http://kokoelmat.fng.fi/app?action=page&lang=fi&si=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.muusa.net%2FE42_Object_Identifier%2FA_IV_3941 Kreeta Haapasalo soittaa kannelta (1957) Suomen kansallisgallerian kokoelmissa.]
[[Category:1868 paintings]] [[Category:Finnish paintings]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]] [[Category:Finnish society]] [[Category:Kalevala]] [[Category:Kantele players]]

page.title: List of films that most frequently use the word "fuck"

revision.text:
{{pp-semi-protected|small=yes}} {{multiple issues| {{Unreliable sources|date=December 2014}} {{original research|date=September 2018}} }} {{dynamic list}} <!-- Please only information from reliable sources. This DOES NOT INCLUDE IMDb because its registered users can add information to an IMDb trivia section without checking the facts. Also, PLEASE read the talk page before nominating this article for deletion. It has been nominated many times already. -->
The use of [[profanity]] in films has always been controversial, but has increased significantly in recent years.<ref>{{cite news |author= |url=http://www.news-medical.net/?id=3330 |title=Violence, sex, and profanity increased significantly in movies between 1992 and 2003 |date=July 15, 2004 |publisher=news-medical.net |accessdate = 2009-01-06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author = Kimberly M. Thompson and Fumie Yokota |title = Violence, Sex, and Profanity in Films: Correlation of Movie Ratings With Content |journal = Medscape General Medicine |volume = 6 |date = July 13, 2004 |url = http://www.kidsrisk.harvard.edu/images/MGMmovies.pdf |accessdate = 2009-01-06 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091222072258/http://www.kidsrisk.harvard.edu/images/MGMmovies.pdf |archivedate = December 22, 2009 |df = }}</ref> The use of the word ''[[fuck]]'' in film draws particular criticism; in 2005, the documentary ''[[Fuck (film)|Fuck]]'' dealt entirely with this phenomenon.<ref>{{cite news |author=Rowan Walker |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0,,1951740,00.html |title=Is this an f-word too far? |date=November 19, 2006 |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate = 2009-01-06 }}</ref> The word ''fuck'' is thought to be the [[taboo]] term used most in American film.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://accurapid.com/journal/37swear.htm |title = The Translation of Swearing in the Dubbing of the Film ''South Park'' into Spanish |author = María Jesús Fernández Fernández |work = In So Many Words: Language Transfer on the Screen |publisher = [[University of Surrey]] |date = 2006-06-21 |accessdate = 2008-02-03 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080228151607/http://accurapid.com/journal/37swear.htm |archivedate = 2008-02-28 |df = }}</ref> The 1927 [[Motion Picture Production Code]], better known as the "Hays Code", banned the use of profanity outright.<ref name=hayscode>{{cite web|last1=Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America|title=Don'ts and Be Carefuls|url=http://www.wabashcenter.wabash.edu/syllabi/w/weisenfeld/rel160/donts.html|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref> The modern [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|MPAA rating system]] assigns a PG-13 rating if a film contains the word. The R rating is normally required if the film contains two utterances or if the word is used in a sexual context. There are exceptions to the rule that one sexual use or two non-sexual uses of "fuck" results in an R rating. In some cases, filmmakers appealed the rating because their target audience might avoid an R-rated film. Censors have been more lenient about the word in films that portray historical events.<ref name=fwordpg13>{{cite news|last1=Ridder|first1=Knight|title=F-word doesn't always equal R rating|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2003-08-28/entertainment/0308270034_1_mpaa-rating-films-f-word|accessdate=3 October 2015|work=Baltimore Sun|date=28 August 2003}}</ref>
This is a list of non-[[pornographic]], [[English language]] films containing at least 150 spoken uses of the word ''fuck'' (or one of its [[derivation (linguistics)|derivatives]]), ordered by the number of such uses.
==List of films by number of uses== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Film ! Year ! ''Fuck'' count ! Minutes ! Uses/minute ! [[#Resources|Source]] ! Ref. <!-- Please add ONLY INFORMATION FROM RELIABLE SOURCES. This DOES NOT INCLUDE IMDB because the information in the IMDB trivia section can be added by registered users without fact checking. Currently, the only known reliable sources are FMG (www.familymediaguide.com) and Screen It (www.screenit.com). --> |- | ''[[Swearnet: The Movie]]'' || 2014 || 935 || 112 || 8.35 || ||<ref>{{cite web|title='Swearnet: The Movie'|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/chi-movie-reviews-pictures-pg-189-photo.html|publisher=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> |- | ''[[Fuck (film)|Fuck]]''—a documentary on the word<ref>An earlier cut of the film, shown at the AFI Los Angeles International Film Festival, [http://www.indiewire.com/ots/2005/11/dispatch_from_l.html incorrectly stated the film contained 629 uses] of the word ''fuck''.</ref> || 2005 || 857|| 93 || 9.21 || ||<ref name="glenngarvin">{{cite news|title=How to hear the F-word 857 times on TV – F**k. 2–4 a.m. Saturday. Documentary Channel.|date=May 27, 2011|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|location=[[Florida]]|first=Glenn|last=Garvin|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|quote=Anybody expecting protective bleeps will suffer lethally seared eardrums within minutes of tuning in; the program shatters all existing records of F-word usage with 857 gloriously stereophonic examples.}}</ref><ref name="zoemak">{{cite news|first=Zoe|last=Mak|title=Entertainment: Director gives the F-word an airing|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/588263/director-gives-f-word-airing|accessdate=April 22, 2013|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|publisher=[[SCMP Group]]|location=[[Hong Kong]]|date=August 12, 2012|quote= But in a movie now being shown in Hong Kong, it is heard no fewer than 857 times. It is 'the F-word', and it is still so controversial that on posters for the documentary of the same name, the 'u' has been replaced by an asterisk.}}</ref> |- | ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]'' || 2013 || 569 || 180 || 3.16 || [[#Resources|SI]] ||<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.screenitplus.com/members/login.cfm?hpage=the_wolf_of_wall_street_Full_Content_Review.cfm |title=The Wolf of Wall Street |publisher=Screenit.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}{{Subscription required}}</ref><!-- Before you change the source to that WeGotThisCovered.com post as a source, please see the talk page. --><ref name = "Slate">{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/07/wolf_of_wall_street_sets_f_word_record_we_counted_every_last_f_bomb_in_the.html |title=Is Wolf of Wall Street Really the Sweariest Movie of All Time? A Slate Investigation |date= |accessdate=2014-01-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/01/wolf-of-wall-street-counting-all-the-curse-words.html|first=Gilbert|last=Cruz|title=Every Single Curse Word Said in The Wolf of Wall Street: The Fullest Picture|publisher=Vulture|date=2014-01-08|accessdate=2014-02-08}}</ref> |- | ''[[Summer of Sam]]'' || 1999 || 435 || 142 || 3.06 || [[#Resources|PO]] ||<ref>The DVD release includes an optional "curse counter" function that keeps a visual record of the number of appearances of the word both verbally and visually in the film. page.title: List of human rights articles by country
Magbo helmet mask for Oro society

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = WLA ima Magbo helmet mask for Oro association.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 150px | title = Magbo helmet mask for Oro society | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Onabanjo of Itu Meko | year = 1880-1910 | type = [[Wood carving]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 28.75 | width_imperial = 13.75 | length_imperial = 18.5 | diameter__metric = | diameter_imperial = | imperial_unit = in | metric_unit = cm | city = [[Indianapolis]] | museum = [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }}
This '''''Magbo helmet mask for an Oro society member''''' was created by [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] artist Onabanjo of Itu Meko. It is currently located in the African collection of the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], which is in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]]. Created around 1880-1910, it depicts a varied cast of community members carved of wood, colored with pigment, and mounted on a curved bar surmounting the helmet.<ref name=lee>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Ellen Wardwell|last2=Robinson|first2=Anne|title=Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection|publisher=Indianapolis Museum of Art|location=Indianapolis|year=2005|isbn=0936260777}}</ref>
==Description== Thirteen distinct figures crown this helmet, including a prisoner, a nursing mother, a preacher, an [[accordion]] player, a soldier, an elder, a [[palmwine]] tapper, and a mounted warrior wearing a helmet of his own, this one topped by an enormous bird.<ref>{{cite book|last=Drewal|first=Henry John|title=Yoruba: Nine Centuries of African Art and Thought|year=1989|publisher=[[H. N. Abrams]]|location=New York}}</ref> This indicates the wide reach of the ''Oro'' society, encompassing the entire community. After 1850, [[Brazil]]ian motifs (such as the double scrolls above the main face and floral clusters throughout) became a common part of the artistic vernacular among the [[Ijebu]] subgroup of the Yoruba people. This is because former slaves returned home, bringing new ideas to the already sophisticated culture.<ref name=ima/>
==Historical information== In Yoruba communities, the secretive ''Oro'' society had immense power. It was composed of community leaders, who would meet to reward good deeds and punish bad ones with everything from chastisement to the death penalty. They also presided over burials.<ref name=lee/>
===Acquisition=== This mask was purchased by Indianapolis philanthropist Harrison Eiteljorg in 1976. He gave it to the IMA in 1989, where it was given the accession number 1989.754. It is currently on view in the Eiteljorg Suite of African and Oceanic Art.<ref name=ima>{{cite web|title=Magbo helmet mask for Oro association|url=http://www.imamuseum.org/collections/artwork/magbo-helmet-mask-oro-association-onabanjo-itu-meko|publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]|accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref>
==Artist== Most African art is unattributed. The unusual practice of nailing the individual figures to the helmet, rather than carving the entire artwork from a single piece of wood, leads scholars to believe that this is the work of master carver Onabanjo, from the village of Itu Meko, [[Nigeria]]. The Brazilian motifs are also in keeping with his work.<ref name=lee/>
==See also== * [[Yoruba art]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.imamuseum.org/collections/artwork/magbo-helmet-mask-oro-association-onabanjo-itu-meko IMA page]. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yRCZJTgV8Uc&feature=youtube_gdata_player Video about the ''Oro'' society].
{{IMAart}}
[[Category:Indianapolis Museum of Art artworks]] [[Category:Yoruba art]] [[Category:Nigerian art]] [[Category:Wooden sculptures in Indiana]] [[Category:Helmets]] [[Category:Masks in Africa]] [[Category:Individual helmets]]

{{Expand German|date=September 2017|Marind-anim}} {{Infobox ethnic group| |group = '''Marind people'''
'''Marind-Anim people''' |image = [[File:Marind-Anim men dressed for ceremony, south coast Dutch New Guinea.jpg|300px]] |caption = Marind-Anim men dressed for ceremony, south coast Dutch New Guinea. c 1920's. |population = 11,000{{cite web|url=http://joshuaproject.net/people_groups/13544/ID |title=Marind in Indonesia |publisher=[[Joshua Project]] |accessdate=2014-09-18}} |popplace = {{flag|Indonesia}} (Southern coast of [[Papua (province)]]) |langs = [[Marind languages|Marind Family]] of the [[Trans–New Guinea languages|Trans–New Guinea Phylum]] of [[Papuan language]]s, [[Indonesian language]] |rels = [[Christianity]] (predominantly), Indigenous beliefs |related = Indigenous [[Papuan peoples]] of [[West Papua (region)|West Papua]] and [[Papua New Guinea]], other [[Melanesians]] }} '''Marind''' or '''Marind-Anim''' are people living in South [[New Guinea]]. == Geography == The Marind- anim live in [[Papua (Indonesian province)|Papua province]] of [[Indonesia]]. They occupy a vast territory, which is situated on either side of the Bian, from about 20 miles to the east of Merauke up the mouth of the Moeli in the west (between Frederik Hendrik Island and the mainland, east of [[Yos Sudarso Island]], mainly west of [[Maro River]] (a small area goes beyond Maro at its lower part, including [[Merauke]]).[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 225 [[File:Marind languages.svg|thumb|center|300px|A map showing New Guinea language groups. The Marind-speaking area is highlighted in red.]] == Topography == The territory of the Marind tribe consist of a low-lying, deposited coastal area. This area is for the most part flooded in the wet season. The hinterland, which is situated somewhat higher is intersected by a great number of rivers. Originally, either sago or coconut palm trees were planted, though stretches of bamboo could also be found. == Culture == Traditionally the social structure of the Marind was characterised by a clan system. Marind-tribe was divided into moitiesm, each consisting of patrilineal clans (boans). These clans are subdivided into subclans (also boans). The people lived spread in several [[Extended family|extended families]]. Such an extended family derives its origin from a mythological ancestor. [[Ancestor veneration]] has a characteristic form here: these mythological ancestors are [[demon]]-like figures, they feature in myths, and act as [[culture hero]]es, arranging the ancient world to its recent state, introducing plants, animals, cultural goods.[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 12 They have often the form of plants or animals; there is a kind of [[totemism]], but it is not accompanied by a regular [[food taboo]] of the respective animal or plant.[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 13 Totems can appear both in artefacts[[#Unknown1920s|Unknown photographer 1920s]] (see postcard image [http://www.oceania-ethnographica.com/mel126.html online]) and myths.[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 86, 202/note 108 (= Die Taube und die Enten) The word for such an ancestral spirit being is ''dema'' in the [[Marind languages]]. The material similarity of this word to “demon” is incidental. Each extended family keeps and transfers the tradition, it is especially the chore of the [[Big man (anthropology)|big men]] of the respective family. The influence of these big men does not go beyond their extended family. In the past, the Marind were famed because of [[headhunting]].[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 9 This was rooted in their belief system and linked to the name-giving of the newborn.[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 111 The skull was believed to contain a [[mana]]-like force.[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: blurb[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 112 The Marind-anim are also notable for their sexual culture. Ritual intercourse (otiv-bombari) with women would take place on the day of a girl's wedding, when after the ceremony she would have sex with her new partner's male kin before having sex with her husband. This ritualistic intercourse would take place during other times as well, such as after the woman has given birth.Keesing, Roger M. & Strathern, Andrew J. (1998), ''Cultural Anthropology: A Contemporary Perspective, 3rd. edition'', p. 120 Marind culture was researched by several [[ethnologist]]s and missionaries. For example, the Swiss [[Paul Wirz]], the German [[Hans Nevermann]],[[#Nev57|Nevermann 1957]]: 7 and the Dutch cultural anthropologist [[Jan van Baal]], who was the Governor of [[Netherlands New Guinea]] from 1953 until 1958.[[#Baal66|Van Baal 1966]]. A comprehensive standard work on Marind-anim culture. The [[Marind languages]] form a small family of the [[Trans–New Guinea languages|Trans–New Guinea]] language phylum.[[#Baal07|Baal 2007]]: Marind-anim, Orientation (see [http://www.everyculture.com/Oceania/Marind-anim-Orientation.html online]) == See also == {{Portal|Indonesia}} * [[Dugout (boat)]] * [[Asmat people]] * [[Sago]] * [[Papuan people]] * [[Papuan mythology]] * [[Swamp]] * [[Digging stick]] * [[Hourglass drum]] * [[Secret society]] == References == === Citations === {{Reflist|32em}} === Sources === * {{cite book |last=Van Baal |first=Jan |title=Dema. {{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2018}} {{distinguish|Miriam language (Nigeria)}} {{Infobox language |name=Meriam |altname=Eastern Torres Strait |region=[[Murray Island, Queensland|Murray Island]], [[Torres Strait]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] |ethnicity=[[Meriam people|Meriam]] |speakers=217 |date=2016 census |ref={{Cite web|url=http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=ABS_C16_T09_SA|title=Census 2016, Language spoken at home by Sex (SA2+)|publisher=ABS|website=stat.data.abs.gov.au|language=en-au|access-date=2017-10-30}} |familycolor=Papuan |fam1=[[Trans-Fly languages|Trans-Fly]] |fam2=[[Eastern Trans-Fly languages|Eastern Trans-Fly]] |sign=[[Eastern Torres Strait Islander Sign Language]] |iso3=ulk |glotto=meri1244 |glottorefname=Meriam |aiatsis=Y3 |lingua=20-OD(A-a) |notice=IPA }} '''Meriam''' (in the language itself ''Meriam Mìr''; also ''Miriam, Meryam, Mer, Mir, Miriam-Mir'', etc. and ''Eastern, Isten, Esten, ,'' and ''Able Able'') or the '''Eastern Torres Strait language''' is the language of the people of the small islands of ''Mer'' ([[Murray Island, Queensland|Murray Island]]), ''Waier'' and ''Dauar'', ''Erub'' ([[Darnley Island (Queensland)|Darnley Island]]), and ''Ugar'' ([[Stephens Island (Torres Strait)|Stephens Island]]) in the eastern [[Torres Strait]], [[Queensland]], Australia. In the Western Torres Strait language, [[Kalaw Lagaw Ya]], it is called ''Mœyam'' or ''Mœyamau Ya''. It is the only [[Papuan language]] in [[Australian]] territory. ==Classification== Meriam was classified in the [[Eastern Trans-Fly languages|Eastern Trans-Fly family]] of the [[Trans–New Guinea languages|Trans–New Guinea]] Phylum by [[Stephen Wurm]], who however felt that these have retained remnants of pre-Trans–New Guinea languages; this is followed by [[Ethnologue]] (2005). In 2005 [[Malcolm Ross (linguist)|Malcolm Ross]] concluded that the Eastern Trans-Fly languages were not part of the Trans–New Guinea phylum. [[R. M. W. Dixon]] (2002) regards claims of a relationship between the Fly River languages and Meriam as unproven, though what he bases his claim on is not clear, as Meriam Mir has a high cognacy rate with its sister languages, and a certain amount of mutual intelligibility is claimed by Meriam speakers. Mitchell finds that Meriam Mìr has 78% cognates with its sister Trans-Fly Papuan languages, the remaining vocabulary being mainly of Australian origin {{sfn|Mitchell|2015}}. Such Trans-Fly cognates include personal pronouns, and verbal and nominal morphology. {| class="wikitable" |+Percentages of Australian, Papuan and Austronesian content
''(2) = number of items; Mitchell and Piper, Holman et al. 40-word list '' ! Source || WCL || MM |- | Australian || 22.5% (9) || 5% (2) |- | Papuan || 22.5% (9) || 62.5% (25) |- | Derivations/Compounds || 20% (8) || 17.5% (7)
[common to Eastern Trans-Fly 15% (6)] |- | Austronesian || 12.5% (5) || 2.5% (1) |- | More than one possible origin || 15% (6) || 17.5% (7) |- | Unclassifiable || 32.5% (13) || 20% (8) |} ==Meriam Mìr and its neighbours== Meriam has around 40 percent of its vocabulary in common with its unrelated Western Torres Strait neighbour [[Kala Lagaw Ya]], which is an [[Australian language]] {{sfn|Mitchell|2015}}. The shared words cover a wide range of semantic domains (body parts, kin, human classification, language, mythology, ceremony, artefacts, topography, natural elements, marine life, qualities, locations, directions and time), though not verbs. This latter strengthens arguments about genetic diversity, however there is still much to suggest mutual influence. The common vocabulary range from "exact cognates" to words that appear related, but have undergone semantic changes, as in the following selected from a list of 250 items (Mitchell 1995) (where exact "cognates" number 62 (24.8%), partial "cognates" 26 (10%) and "cognates" with semantic differentiation number 34 (13.7%)): {| class="wikitable" |+Exact "cognates" ! Mitchell and Piper (unpublished research notes) used the Holman et al. 40-word list below, which shows 9 (22.5%) exact items, 5 (12.5%) partial, and 3 (7.5%) semantically related words. However, this list was designed for use with Euro-Asian languages, and is perhaps somewhat inappropriate; for example, no horned animals exist, neither language has a verb ‘come’, and Holman et al. assume one form for 'we'; WCL has 4, and MM has 2. kari, karian ''little, small'' || kirece, mamye, cireni, mamie~karte ''new'';
matimati, matikäli, matikolä, matikola, matikari, geglo ''little, small'' || sisel, sisɨl || *kari[kari]/*kira[kira] || oliómoto || -- || kayin(a)|| -- || -- || -- || -- |- | '''dog''' || omai || umai, umae, ume || drenggo, drego, drengo || yongg, yongk, yongga, yangg, yoorɨnk || *omái || Kerewo kaukau, Kope umu || dréngg || ùmai || ingkud[h]iinya || Y/At/A utagha || *gudaga || -- |- | '''sun, day''' || gerger "day, daylight"
lìm "sun" || abüs, óbüs || bimu, abeji, abweji, abuji;
gugie, griga "star" || bibɨr ''day'', lom, lomkongga, lemkogal, ganggal ''sun''
(konga, kogal "woman") || *limͻ/*lͻmi || M iwio, Parama ivio, Kerewo hewio, Kope hivio ''sun'';
sai ''day'' || yébodh ''sun'' || gœiga, gœygœyi-, gœigi-,
OKY gœRigaR(i) || inga || Y/At/A wunga, W unga, W mungbatho ''day'' || *gari, *wuŋa || -- |- |} ==Recent loans== The main source of loan words to the language since the mid 1800s has been Yumplatòk ([[Torres Strait Creole]]) and English. There are also some minor loans from [[Dehu language|Lifu/Drehu]], Polynesian (in particular [[Samoan language|Samoan]] and to a lesser extent [[Rotuman language|Rotuman]]), Indonesian, Philippine, Japanese, and European origin. Many such outsiders were recruited – or in some rare cases [[black-birded]] – in the 19th century for pearl diving and other marine work, while others (from Lifu and Samoa) were missionaries with the British and Foreign Bible Society. ==Dialects== The language is currently dialectless. However, there was once a separate dialect spoken on [[Darnley Island (Queensland)|Erub]] and [[Stephens Island (Torres Strait)|Ugar]] islands, characterised in part by the retention of phonemic distinctions between 'ng', 'g', 'n' and 'r' where these have fallen together in two ways in Meriam Mir. The sound 'ng' in Modern Meriam has become 'n' at the beginning of words and 'g' within words; 'n' in many cases has become 'r' within words. Examples are remembered in one important Erub folktale (Lawrie 1970:283–284): Erub : '''Aka nade ki andinane? Ge au?''' Mer : '''Aka nade ki ardirare? Ge au?''' ''Where will we put it? There?'' Erub : '''Mena inggandane/ingandane! Keniba uzen unken a keniba imut unken.''' Mer : '''Mena igardare! Keriba uzer urker a keriba imut urker.''' ''Keep carrying it! Our paddles and our poling poles are still strong.'' The earliest records (early 19th century) of Meriam Mìr included the phrase '''debelang''' ''good taste/nice'', in present-day Meriam Mìr '''debe lag'''. This shows that the 'ng' > 'n'/'g' change is of fairly recent date; '''lang''', now '''lag''', is identical to the [[Gizrra language|Gizrra]] '''lang''' of the same meaning. ==Phonology== ===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[High vowel|High]] | {{IPA|i}} {{Angbr|i}} | {{IPA|u}} {{Angbr|u}} |- ! [[High vowel|Retracted High]] | {{IPA|ɪ}} {{Angbr|i}}{{Angbr|e}}{{Angbr|ì}} | {{IPA|ʊ}} {{Angbr|u}}{{Angbr|ù}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|e}} {{Angbr|e}} | {{IPA|o}} {{Angbr|o}} |- ! [[Low vowel|Low]] | {{IPA|a}}, {{IPA|ʌ}} {{Angbr|a}} | {{IPA|ɔ}} {{Angbr|o}}{{Angbr|ò}} |} The sounds represented by {{IPA|[a]}} and {{IPA|[ʌ]}} are allophonic. {{IPA|[ʌ]}} appears mainly in syllables ''before'' the stress accent and optionally in open unstressed syllables otherwise. {{IPA|[a]}} appears in stressed syllables and in unstressed closed syllables. For some speakers the following pairs exhibit variation, and perhaps have unidentified allophonic variation: {{IPA|[e]}} and {{IPA|[ɪ]}} (mainly Erub/Ulag), {{IPA|[ɪ]}} and {{IPA|[i]}} (mainly Mer), {{IPA|[u]}} and {{IPA|[ʊ]}}, {{IPA|[ʊ]}} and {{IPA|[o]}}, and {{IPA|[o]}} and {{IPA|[ɔ]}}. Older speakers appear to keep the vowels more distinct. ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" !colspan="2"| ! [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Dental]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveo-Palatal]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Velar]] |- !rowspan="2"| [[Stop consonant|Stop]] ! [[Voiceless consonant|Voiceless]] | {{IPA|p}} | {{IPA|t}} | | | {{IPA|k}} |- ! [[Voiced consonant|Voiced]] | {{IPA|b}} | | {{IPA|d}} | | {{IPA|ɡ}} |- !colspan="2"| [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA|m}} | {{IPA|n}} | | | |- !rowspan="2"| [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! [[Voiceless consonant|Voiceless]] | | | | {{IPA|s}} | |- ! [[Voiced consonant|Voiced]] | | | | {{IPA|z}} | |- !colspan="2"| [[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | {{IPA|l}} | | | |- !colspan="2"| [[Trill consonant|Trill]]/[[Flap consonant|Tap]] | | | {{IPA|r}} | | |- !colspan="2"| [[Semivowel]] | {{IPA|w}} | | | {{IPA|y}} | |} ===Stress=== [[Stress (linguistics)|Stress]] is contrastive in Meriam and can occur on the first or second syllable. Examples include ''tábo'' 'snake', ''tabó'' 'neck'''. ==Sign language== The Torres Strait Islanders have [[manually coded language|signed forms]] of their languages,[[Alfred Cort Haddon|Haddon, Alfred C.]] (1907). ''The gesture language of the Eastern Islanders,'' in "Reports of the Cambridge Anthropological Expedition to Torres Straits." Cambridge, England: The University Press, v.3. though it is not clear from records that they are particularly well-developed compared to other [[Australian Aboriginal sign languages]].[[Adam Kendon|Kendon, A.]] (1988) ''Sign Languages of Aboriginal Australia: Cultural, Semiotic and Communicative Perspectives.'' Cambridge: Cambridge University Press ==See also== *[[Torres Strait Island languages]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book |last=Dixon |first=R. M. W. |authorlink=R. M. W. Dixon |year=2002 |title=Australian Languages: Their Nature and Development |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |url=http://www.cambridge.org/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=0521473780}} * {{citation |last=Mitchell |first=Rod |authorlink=R. Mitchell |date=April 2015 |title=Ngalmun Lagaw Yangukudu: The Language of our Homeland ''in'' Goemulgaw Lagal: Cultural and Natural Histories of the Island of Mabuyag, Torres Strait |journal=Memoirs of the Queensland Museum: Culture |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=323–446 |issn=1440-4788 }} *{{cite book |last=Passi |first=Gamalai Ken |author2=Piper, Nick |year=1994 |chapter=Meryam Mir |editor=Nick Thieberger |editor2=William McGregor |title=Macquarie Aboriginal Words |publisher=Macquarie Library |pages=320–351}} *{{cite book |last=Piper |first=N. |year=1989 |title=A sketch grammar of Meryam Mer |others=MA thesis |publisher=Australian National University}} *{{cite book |last=Ross |first=Malcolm |authorlink=Malcolm Ross (linguist) |year=2005 |chapter=Pronouns as a preliminary diagnostic for grouping Papuan languages |editor=Andrew Pawley |editor2=Robert Attenborough |editor3=Robin Hide |editor4=Jack Golson |title=Papuan pasts: cultural, linguistic and biological histories of Papuan-speaking peoples |pages=15–66 |location=Canberra |publisher=Pacific Linguistics}} *{{cite book |last=Lawrie |first=Margaret |year=1970 |title=Myths and Legends of Torres Strait |location=St. Lucia |publisher=University of Queensland Press}} ==External links== *[http://justus.anglican.org/resources/bcp/PNG/meriam_hc.html Opolera Wetpur] Anglican Holy Communion service in Meriam {{Torres Strait |state=autocollapse}} {{Languages of Australia}} [[Category:Eastern Trans-Fly languages]] [[Category:Torres Strait Islands culture]] [[Category:Languages of Australia]]
