In practice this law (like the law forbidding dowries) is widely ignored, and levels of abortion on female foetuses remain high and the sex ratio at birth keeps getting more skewed. <ref name="India's lost daughters"/>
Female infanticide (killing of infant girls) is still prevalent in some rural areas.<ref name="un_women_free_equal" /> Sometimes this is infanticide by neglect, for example families may not spend money on critical medicines or withhold care from a sick girl.
Continuing abuse of the dowry tradition has been one of the main reasons for sex-selective abortions and female infanticides in India.
===Honor killings=== [[Honor killing]]s have been reported in [[North India|northern regions of India]], mainly in the Indian states of [[Punjab (Indian state)|Punjab]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Haryana]] and [[Uttar Pradesh]], as a result of the girl marrying without the family's acceptance, and sometimes for marrying outside her [[caste system in India|caste]] or religion. Haryana is notorious for incidents of honour killings, which have been described as "chillingly common in villages of Haryana".<ref>{{cite news |title=Indian media express anger over 'honour killings' |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-24170937 |publisher=[[BBC news]] |date=20 September 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> In contrast, honor killings are rare to non-existent in [[South India]] and the western Indian states of [[Maharashtra]] and [[Gujarat]]. In some other parts of India, notably [[West Bengal]], honor killings completely ceased about a century ago, largely due to the activism and influence of [[Hindu reform movements|reformists]] such as [[Vivekananda]], [[Ramakrishna]], [[Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar|Vidyasagar]] and [[Raja Ram Mohan Roy]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Cook |first=Sharell |title=Honour killings in India (blog) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524070439/http://www.whiteindianhousewife.com/2010/06/honour-killings-in-india/ |archivedate=24 May 2014 |url=http://www.whiteindianhousewife.com/2010/06/honour-killings-in-india/ |date=16 June 2010 |website=whiteindianhousewife.com |publisher=Diary of a White Indian Housewife / Daily Life in India |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref> In 2010, the [[Supreme Court of India]] issued notice in regard to honor killings to the states of [[Punjab (Indian state)|Punjab]], [[Haryana]], [[Bihar]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Jharkhand]], [[Himachal Pradesh]] and [[Madhya Pradesh]].<ref name="bbc.com">{{cite news |title=India court seeks 'honour killing' response |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/10364986 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 June 2010 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
===Accusations of witchcraft=== Violence against women related to accusations of witchcraft occurs in India, particularly in parts of [[Northern India]]. Belief in the supernatural among the Indian population is strong, and [[lynching]]s for witchcraft are reported by the media.<ref>{{cite news |last=Singh |first=Rao Jaswant |title=Branded witch, tribal woman forced to dip hands in hot oil |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jaipur/Branded-witch-tribal-woman-forced-to-dip-hands-in-hot-oil/articleshow/3578363.cms? |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=10 October 2008 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> In [[Assam]] and [[West Bengal]] between 2003 and 2008 there were around 750 deaths related to accusations of witchcraft.<ref name=Witch>{{cite news |last=Blakely |first=Rhys |title=Witchcraft is given a spell in India’s schools to remove curse of deadly superstition |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/asia/article2609335.ece |work=[[The Times]] |date=24 November 2008 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> Officials in the state of [[Chhattisgarh]] reported in 2008 that at least 100 women are maltreated annually as suspected witches.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fifty 'witches' beaten by mob |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073536/http://news.sky.com/story/657468/fifty-witches-beaten-by-mob |archivedate=4 March 2016 |url=http://news.sky.com/story/657468/fifty-witches-beaten-by-mob |agency=[[Sky News]] |date=22 December 2008}}</ref>
===Rape=== {{Main|Rape in India}} [[File:Delhi protests-India Raped, says one young woman's sign.jpg|thumb|People in [[Delhi]], [[India]] protesting after a young student was [[2012 Delhi gang rape case|gang-raped in Delhi]] in December 2012.]] [[Rape in India]] has been described by [[Radha Kumar]] as one of India's most common crimes against women<ref name="Kumar">{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68xTBT1-H4IC&printsec=frontcover |last=Kumar |first=Radha|author-link=Radha Kumar |contribution=The agitation against rape|editor-last=Kumar|editor-first=Radha|editor-link=Radha Kumar |title=The history of doing: an illustrated account of movements for women's rights and feminism in India 1800-1990 |page=128 |publisher=Zubaan |location=New Delhi |year=2003 |origyear=1993 |isbn=9788185107769 |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> and by the [[UN]]’s human-rights chief as a "national problem".<ref>{{cite news |title=India’s women: Rape and murder in Delhi |url=https://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21569031-horrible-attack-could-prove-turning-point-indias-women-rape-and-murder-delhi |work=[[The Economist]] |date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> Since the 1980s, women's rights groups lobbied for [[marital rape]] to be declared unlawful,<ref name="Kumar"/> but the [[Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013]] still maintains the marital exemption by stating in its exception clause under Section 375, that: "Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his own wife, the wife not being under fifteen years of age, is not rape".<ref>{{cite news |title=The Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013 |url=http://indiacode.nic.in/acts-in-pdf/132013.pdf |work=[[The Gazette of India]] |publisher=Government of India |year=2013}}</ref> While per-capita reported incidents are quite low compared to other countries, even developed countries,<ref>{{cite web |last=Goel |first=Sharad |url=http://messymatters.com/rape/ |title=Lies, damned lies, rape, and statistics (blog) |publisher=Messy Matters |date=25 January 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{citation |last1=Humphrey |first1=John A. |last2=Schmalleger |first2=Frank |contribution=Mental illness, addictive behaviors, and sexual deviance|editor-last1=Humphrey|editor-first1=John A.|editor-last2=Schmalleger|editor-first2=Frank |title=Deviant behavior |page=252 |publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning |location=Sudbury, Massachusetts |year=2012 |edition=2nd |isbn=9780763797737 |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> a new case is reported every 20 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mohanty |first1=Suchitra |last2=Daniel |first2=Frank Jack |title=Indian rape victim's father says he wants her named |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/01/06/us-india-rape-idUSBRE90500B20130106 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=6 January 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref name=indiatribune>{{cite news |title=Rape statistics around the world |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308052811/http://www.indiatribune.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=10195:rape-statistics-around-the-world-&catid=107:coverpage&Itemid=471 |archivedate=8 March 2015 |url=http://www.indiatribune.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=10195:rape-statistics-around-the-world-&catid=107:coverpage&Itemid=471 |work=[[India Tribune]] |date=11 September 2012 |accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref>
New Delhi has one of the highest rate of rape-reports among Indian cities.<ref name=indiatribune/> Sources show that rape cases in India have doubled between 1990 and 2008.<ref name="AFP">{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |title=Indian student gang-raped, thrown off bus in New Delhi |url=http://www.arabnews.com/indian-student-gang-raped-thrown-bus-new-delhi |work=[[Arab News]] |date=17 December 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Ganguly |first=Meenakshi, South Asia director |title=India: Rape victim’s death demands action |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/12/29/india-rape-victim-s-death-demands-action |work=[[Human Rights Watch]] |date=29 December 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
===Sexual harassment=== {{Main|Eve teasing}}
[[Eve teasing]] is a euphemism used for sexual harassment or molestation of women by men. Many activists blame the rising incidents of sexual harassment against women on the influence of "Western culture". In 1987, The Indecent Representation of Women (Prohibition) Act was passed<ref name=Ind_Rep>{{cite web |title=The Indecent Representation of Women (Prohibition) Act, 1987 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140922130043/http://wcd.nic.in/dowryprohibitionrules.htm |archivedate=22 September 2014 |url=http://www.wcd.nic.in/dowryprohibitionrules.htm |website=wcd.nic.in |publisher=[[Ministry of Women and Child Development]] |date=25 September 1987 |accessdate=24 December 2006}}</ref> to prohibit indecent representation of women through advertisements or in publications, writings, paintings or in any other manner.
Of the total number of crimes against women reported in 1990, half related to molestation and harassment in the workplace.<ref name="un_women_free_equal"/> In 1997, in a landmark judgement{{ambiguous|date=March 2013}}, the Supreme Court of India took a strong stand against sexual harassment of women in the workplace. The Court also laid down detailed guidelines for prevention and redressal of grievances. The National Commission for Women subsequently elaborated these guidelines into a Code of Conduct for employers.<ref name="un_women_free_equal"/> In 2013 India's top court investigated on a law graduate's allegation that she was sexually harassed by a recently retired Supreme Court judge.<ref>{{cite news |title=India Supreme Court investigates ex-judge for sexual harassment |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-24909511 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=12 November 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act came into force in December 2013, to prevent Harassment of women at workplace.
A study by [[ActionAid]] UK found that 80% of women in India had experienced sexual harassment ranging from unwanted comments, being groped or assaulted. Many incidents go unreported as the victims fear [[Victim blaming|being shunned by their families]].<ref name="reuters_26May2016">{{cite news |last=Bhalla |first=Nita |title=Almost 80 percent of Indian women face public harassment in cities - survey |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/india-women-harassment-cities-idINKCN0YE23R |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=23 May 2016 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
===Trafficking=== The Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act was passed in 1956.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151020053429/http://wcd.nic.in/act/itpa1956.htm |archivedate=20 October 2015 |url=http://wcd.nic.in/act/itpa1956.htm |website=wcd.nic.in |publisher=[[Ministry of Women and Child Development]] |accessdate=24 December 2006}}</ref> However many cases of [[human trafficking|trafficking]] of young girls and women have been reported. These women are forced into prostitution or domestic work or [[child labour]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}

==Women's rights== Centre for Equality and Inclusion (CEQUIN), alternatively spelled in the press as Center for Equality and Inclusion, is a non-governmental organisation based in India that works towards female empowerment and women's rights.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
==Other concerns== [[File:Santal_people_Jharkhand_India.jpg|thumb|Women in [[Jharkhand]]]]
===Social opinions=== {{Main|History of sex in India}} In the wake of several brutal rape attacks in the capital city of Delhi, debates held in other cities revealed that some men believed women who dressed provocatively deserved to get raped; many of the correspondents stated women incited men to rape them.<ref>{{cite news |last=Chamberlain |first=Gethin |title='If girls look sexy, boys will rape.' Is this what Indian men really believe? | World news | Baga, Goa |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/24/india-rape-disturbing-attitudes-men |work=[[The Observer]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |location=London |date=24 March 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Chamberlain |first=Gethin |title=Why young Indian men rationalize rape as something expected |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2013/03/26/2003558007 |work=[[Taipei Times]] |location=Taiwan |date=1 February 2014 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
===Participation of women in social life=== The degree to which women participate in public life, that is being outside the home, varies by region and background. For example, the [[Rajput]]s, a patrilineal clan inhabiting parts of India, especially the north-western area, have traditionally practiced [[purdah|ghunghat]], and many still do to this day. In recent years however, more women have started to challenge such social norms: for instance women in rural [[Haryana]] are increasingly rejecting the [[ghunghat]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Jolly |first=Asit |title='The ghunghat no longer works for me. It holds me back' |url=https://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/haryana-rural-women-throw-off-the-veil-to-empower-themselves/1/223586.html |work=[[India Today]] |date=5 October 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> In India, most population (about two thirds)<ref name="CIA_India">{{cite web |title=The World Factbook: South Asia: India |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/in.html |publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]}}</ref> is rural, and, as such, lives in tight-knit communities where it is very easy for a woman to ruin her family's 'honor' through her behavior. The concept of [[family honor]] is especially prevalent in northern India. [[Izzat (honour)|Izzat]] is a concept of honor prevalent in the culture of North India and [[Pakistan]].<ref name="ref14fohaz">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rtBi1MgVD0AC&pg=PA99 |last=Cheesman |first=David |contribution=The backbone of the country|editor-last=Cheesman|editor-first=David |title=Landlord power and rural indebtedness in colonial Sind, 1865-1901 |page=99 |publisher=Curzon Press |location=Richmond, Surrey |year=1997 |isbn=9780700704705 |quote=''... Izzat remains to this day a critical part of life throughout Pakistan and northern India. Maintaining izzat is a driving motivation for vast numbers of people, from all communities and classes and in every walk of life ...'' |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> Izzat applies to both sexes, but in different ways. Women must uphold the 'family honor' by being chaste, passive and submissive, while men must be strong, brave, and be willing and able to control the women of their families.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vishwanath |first1=Jyothi |last2=Palakonda |first2=Srinivas C. |title=Patriarchal ideology of honour and honour crimes in India |journal=International Journal of Criminal Justice Sciences |volume=6 |issue=1–2 |pages=386–395 |date=January–December 2011 |url=http://www.sascv.org/ijcjs/pdfs/jyothiiicjs2011i&iind.pdf |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> The rural areas surrounding [[Delhi]] are among the most conservative in India: it has been estimated that 30% of all honor killings of India take place in [[Western Uttar Pradesh]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Jeelani |first=Gulam |title=30% honour killings of the country in west UP: AIDWA survey |url=http://english.pradesh18.com/news/uttar-pradesh/30-honour-killings-of-the-country-in-west-up-aidwa-survey-830059.html |website=[[CNN-News18|News18.com]] |agency=[[CNN]] |date=29 October 2015 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> while Haryana has been described as "one of India's most conservative when it comes to caste, marriage and the role of women. Deeply patriarchal, caste purity is paramount and marriages are arranged to sustain the status quo."<ref>{{cite news |last=Denyer |first=Simon |title=Haryana village proud after double "honour killing" |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-33604820080516 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
===Health=== [[File:Community health worker gives a vaccination in Odisha state, India (8380317750).jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Community health worker]] preparing a [[vaccine]] in [[Odisha]]]] {{main|Women's health in India}} The average female life expectancy today in India is low compared to many countries, but it has shown gradual improvement over the years. In many families, especially rural ones, girls and women face nutritional discrimination within the family, and are anaemic and malnourished.<ref name="un_women_free_equal"/> Almost half of adolescent girls are chronically malnourished.<ref name="Fanta_Project">{{cite book |last=Food and Nutrition Technical Assistance (FANTA) |title=India: Nutrition profile |url=http://www.fantaproject.org/sites/default/files/download/India-Nutrition-Profile-Mar2014.pdf |publisher=[[USAID]] |date=March 2014}}</ref> In addition, poor nutrition during pregnancy often leads to birth complications.<ref name="Fanta_Project"/>
The [[Maternal death|maternal mortality]] in India is the 56th highest in the world.<ref name="CIA_Maternal">{{cite web |title=The World Factbook: Country Comparison: Maternal Mortality Rate |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2223rank.htmlpublisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]}}</ref> 42% of births in the country are supervised in Medical Institution. In rural areas, most of women deliver with the help of women in the family, contradictory to the fact that the unprofessional or unskilled deliverer lacks the knowledge about pregnancy.<ref name="un_women_free_equal"/>
===Family planning=== {{Main|Family planning in India}} The average woman living in a rural area in India has little or no control over becoming pregnant. Women, particularly in rural areas, do not have access to safe and self-controlled methods of contraception. The public health system emphasises permanent methods like sterilisation, or long-term methods like IUDs that do not need follow-up. Sterilisation accounts for more than 75% of total contraception, with female sterilisation accounting for almost 95% of all sterilisations.<ref name="un_women_free_equal"/> The contraceptive prevalence rate for 2007/2008 was estimated at 54.8%.<ref name="CIA_India"/>
===Women from lower castes=== Lower caste women in India have seen significant improvement in their status. Educated and financially well-off Dalit women used politics to achieve status, however, that many Dalit women who were involved in politics later declined due to increasing income and educational levels.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7TgkDwAAQBAJ |title=Dalit Women: Vanguard of an Alternative Politics in India |publisher=Taylor & Francis |author=S. Anandhi, Karin Kapadia |year=2017|isbn=9781351797184 }}</ref> The status of Dalit women within households is also noted to have been improved.<ref>{{cite book |title=Dalits in Neoliberal India: Mobility Or Marginalisation? |page=231 |author=Clarinda Still |year=2015 |publisher=Routledge}}</ref>
===Sex ratios=== [[File:Sex determination ban.JPG|thumb|A sign in an Indian hospital stating that prenatal sex determination is a crime.]] India has a highly skewed sex ratio, which is attributed to sex-selective abortion and female infanticide affecting approximately one million female babies per year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Indian girl Infanticide-Female Fetocide: 1 million girls killed before or after birth per year |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215070213/http://rupeenews.com/2008/04/indian-girl-infanticide-female-foeticide-1-million-girls-killed-before-or-after-birth-per-year/ |archivedate=15 December 2012 |url=http://rupeenews.com/2008/04/indian-girl-infanticide-female-foeticide-1-million-girls-killed-before-or-after-birth-per-year/ |work=Rupee News |date=28 September 2009 |accessdate=20 February 2013}}</ref> In, 2011, government stated India was missing three million girls and there are now 48 less girls per 1,000 boys.<ref>{{cite news |author=PTI |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/india-loses-3-million-girls-in-infanticide/article3981575.ece |title=India loses 3 million girls in infanticide |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=9 October 2012 |accessdate=20 February 2013 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref> Despite this, the government has taken further steps to improve the ratio, and the ratio is reported to have been improved in recent years.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ahmad |first=Faiz |title=Sex ratio in India showing improvement |url=http://www.nationalturk.com/en/sex-ratio-in-india-showing-improvement-41907 |work=National Turk |date=21 August 2013 |accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref>
The number of missing women totaled 100 million across the world.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Basu |first=Alaka Malwade |title=Fertility decline and increasing gender imbalance in India, including a possible South Indian turnaround |journal=[[Development and Change]] |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=237–263 |doi=10.1111/1467-7660.00116 |date=April 1999 |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> The male-to-female ratio is high in favor toward men in developing countries in Asia, including India, than that of areas such as North America. Along with abortion, the high ratio of men in India is a result of sex selection, where physicians are given the opportunity to incorrectly determine the sex of a child during the ultrasound.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Doskoch |first=P. |title=Skewed sex ratio of births in India may be the result of sex-selective abortion |journal=[[International Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health|International Family Planning Perspectives]] |volume=32 |issue=2 |pages=102–103 |date=June 2006 |url=https://www.guttmacher.org/journals/ipsrh/2006/06/skewed-sex-ratio-births-india-may-be-result-sex-selective-abortion |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> India currently has a problem known as the "missing women", but it has been present for quite some time. The female mortality in 2001 was 107.43.<ref name="Lane, T. 2004">{{cite journal |last=Lane |first=Trevor |title='''Update''': Contraceptive use around the globe / Child sex ratios continue to decline in India / Circumcision lowers risk of HIV, not other STIs / Herpes risk factors in rural Costa Rica / Fathers make a difference / Infant mortality in China rises with parity / Reproductive health among Caribbean youth / In brief |journal=[[International Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health|International Family Planning Perspectives]] |volume=30 |issue=2 |page=56 |date=June 2004 |url=https://www.guttmacher.org/journals/ipsrh/2004/06/update |ref=harv |postscript=.}}</ref> The deaths of these "missing women" were attributed to the death history rate of women in India starting in 1901.
The gap between the two gender titles is a direct response to the gender bias within India. Men and women in India have unequal health and education rights. Male education and health are made more of a priority, so women’s death rates are increasing.<ref name="Lane, T. 2004"/> The argument continues that a lack of independence that women are not allowed to have is a large contributor to these fatalities. Women in India have high fertility and get married at a young age. Those who are given more opportunity and rights are more likely to live longer and contribute to the economy rather than that of a women expected to serve as wife starting at a young age and continuing the same responsibilities for the rest of her life. As women continue to "disappear," the sex ratio turns its favor toward men. In turn, this offsets reproduction and does not allow for a controlled reproductive trend. While the excess mortality of women is relatively high, it cannot be blamed completely for the unequal sex ratio in India. However, it is a large contributor considering the precedence that Indian men have over women.
===Sanitation=== {{Further|Sanitation in India}}
In rural areas, schools have been reported to have gained the improved sanitation facility.<ref>{{cite book |last=Walker |first=Angela |title=In rural India, improved sanitation and iron supplements help girls stay in school |url=http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/india_55555.html |publisher=[[UNICEF]] |location=India |date=13 August 2010}}</ref> Given the existing socio-cultural norms and situation of sanitation in schools, girl students are forced not to relieve themselves in the open unlike boys.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bisoee |first=Animesh |title=School minus loo is public urinal – Girls answer natures call outside campus; slum dwellers defecate on playground |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1131214/jsp/jharkhand/story_17679434.jsp#.UyCMB87utH0 |location=Calcutta, India |work=[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> Lack of facilities in home forces women to wait for the night to relieve themselves and avoid being seen by others.<ref>{{cite book |title=Water, environment and sanitation |url=http://www.unicef.org/india/wes.html |publisher=UNICEF |location=India}}</ref> Access to sanitation in Bihar has been discussed. According to an estimate from 2013, about 85% of the rural households in [[Bihar]] have no access to a toilet; and this creates a dangerous situation for women and girls who are followed, attacked and raped in the fields.<ref>{{cite news |last=Tewary |first=Amarnath |title=India Bihar rapes 'caused by lack of toilets' |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-22460871 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=9 May 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
In 2011 a "Right to Pee" (as called by the media) campaign began in [[Mumbai]], India's largest city.<ref name=nytimes1>{{cite news |last=Yardley |first=Jim |title=In Mumbai, a campaign against restroom injustice |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/15/world/asia/in-mumbai-a-campaign-against-restroom-injustice.html?pagewanted=all |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=15 June 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> Women, but not men, have to pay to urinate in Mumbai, despite regulations against this practice. Women have also been sexually assaulted while urinating in fields.<ref name=nytimes1/> Thus, activists have collected more than 50,000 signatures supporting their demands that the local government stop charging women to urinate, build more toilets, keep them clean, provide sanitary napkins and a trash can, and hire female attendants.<ref name=nytimes1/> In response, city officials have agreed to build hundreds of public toilets for women in Mumbai, and some local legislators are now promising to build toilets for women in every one of their districts.<ref name=nytimes1/>

===Historiography=== *{{citation |last=Basu |first=Aparna |contribution=Women's History in India: An Historiographical Survey|editor-last1=Offen|editor-first1=Karen|editor-last2=Pierson|editor-first2=Ruth Roach|editor-last3=Rendall|editor-first3=Jane |title=Writing Women's History: International Perspectives |page=181 |year=1991 |ref=harv |postscript=.|hdl = 2027/heb.03316.0001.001}} *{{cite journal |last=Forbes |first=Geraldine Hancock |title=Reflections on South Asian Women's/Gender History: Past and Future |journal=[[Journal of Colonialism and Colonial History]] |volume=4 |issue=1 |doi=10.1353/cch.2003.0012 |date=Spring 2003 |ref=harv |postscript=.}} *{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0121vD9STIMC&pg=PA1318 |last=Pande |first=Rekha |contribution=Women's History: India|editor-last=Boyd|editor-first=Kelly |title=Encyclopedia of Historians and Historical Writing vol 2 |year=1999 |pages=1318–1321 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |ref=harv |postscript=.|isbn=9781884964336 }} *{{citation |last=Ramusack |first=Barbara N. |contribution=Women in South Asia|editor-last1=Ramusack|editor-first1=Barbara N.|editor-last2= Sievers|editor-first2=Sharon L. |title=Women in Asia: restoring women to history |publisher=Indiana University Press |location=Bloomington, Indiana |year=1999 |isbn=9780253212672 |ref=harv |postscript=.}}

revision.text:
'''Youth in Mongolia''' constituted 18.7% of the population in 2014, numbering roughly 552 thousand individuals.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = History of Mongolia|url = http://mongolianembassy.us/about-mongolia/history/#.ViasZH6rTIU|website = Embassy of Mongolia|accessdate = 2015-10-20|language = English|date = 2013-05-21}}</ref> The 15-19 age group is the largest in [[Mongolia]]; in 2009 about 40% of the population was under 19 years old.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Mongolia Facts, information, pictures {{!}} Encyclopedia.com articles about Mongolia|url = http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Mongolia.aspx|website = www.encyclopedia.com|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> Estimated population growth rates as of 2014 were reported as increasing by 1.37%.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Social relations, networks and social organisation in post-socialist rural Mongolia|last = Sneath|first = David|date = 1993-01-01|journal = Nomadic Peoples|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 33|pages = 193–207}}</ref> The steady increase in youth will enlarge the already large proportion of working-aged individuals and create new opportunities to build human capital and facilitate economic development.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|title = Health Sector Reform and Sexual and Reproductive Health Services in Mongolia|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0968808006272264|journal = Reproductive Health Matters|pages = 91–100|volume = 14|issue = 27|doi = 10.1016/s0968-8080(06)27226-4|pmid = 16713883|first = Peter S|last = Hill|first2 = Rebecca|last2 = Dodd|first3 = Khurelmaa|last3 = Dashdorj|year = 2006}}</ref> [[File:Mongolia 063.JPG|thumb|Young Mongolian women prepare for an archery shoot]]In order to address Mongolia's economic future, Mongolia's Parliament adopted the State Population Development Policy in 2004 to confront development issues facing Mongolian youth. This policy and the Mongolia National Programme on Adolescents and Youth Development defined youth as those from ages 15 to 34 years and aims to provide opportunities and services that build youth into well developed citizens.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|title = UNICEF Mongolia - About us - Situation of children|url = http://www.unicef.org/mongolia/overview_24547.html|website = www.unicef.org|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> Mongolia is in the process of transitioning from its status as a [[developing country]] to a nation with a developing economy.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://www.wpro.who.int/topics/adolescent_health/mongolia_fs.pdf|title = Health of Adolescents in Mongolia|date = |accessdate = October 21, 2015|website = |publisher = World Health Organization- Western Pacific Region|last = |first = }}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = School-to-work-transitions in Mongolia|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/23533909|website = ResearchGate|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> According to the [[Human Development Index]], conditions in Mongolia have been improving in recent years, but its ranking on the [[Human Poverty Index]] has dropped further due to the privatization of the economic sector.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" />
Mongolia's political structure has changed frequently since its founding in 1206. In the most recent transition to [[Parliamentary system|democracy]] in 1992, Mongolia incorporated policies directed towards youth.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal |title = Mongolian Youth Outlook Country Profile|last = Ganbat|first = Damba|date = 2012|journal =Democratic Citizenship and Voices of Asia's Youth|url= http://www.asianbarometer.org/publications//f0bdb30ebeb9c77513b4d31bfd10c4da.pdf|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Mongolia became one of the first countries to ratify the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] in 1990 and signed the second and third optional protocols in 2000 and 2013 respectively.<ref name=":9" /> Many of Mongolia’s laws and policies attempt to protect and better the lives of Mongolian youth.The legal age of majority occurs at 18, wherein Mongolian young adults are able to vote and assume legal authority.<ref name=":10" /> The [[Mongolia#Modern history|transition]] from a Soviet satellite state to a sovereign nation in 1992 fueled major structural changes in Mongolian youth lives. Access to education, employment, and health care has increased.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":9" />
== Education == The transition to a [[Market economy|market based economy]] has impacted the [[Mongolian education system]] and labor market.<ref name=":1" /> The formal school system comprises pre-school, primary, secondary and higher education. Based on Soviet models, the Mongolian education system requires 10 years of schooling.The current system has a 4+4+2 structure; four years of primary education, four years of basic or incomplete secondary education, and complete secondary school for the final two years.<ref name=":1" /> The Mongolian Constitution, Education Law, and the Law on Primary and Secondary Education dictates that eight years of compulsory education are free.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":0" />
=== Males verse Females === Before 1990, education attainment was higher than the current rate. Rural and urban boys are prone to dropping out of school to obtain low skill and low wage employment. The World Health Organization found in 2007 that 8,775 school-aged children were not in school. Of these 8,775 children, 59.1% of drop-outs were boys and of this percentage 91.3% were boys from rural areas.<ref name=":1" /> Rural boys are two times more likely to receive no education at all or have below compulsory education over girls due to the need for boys to help their family herd cattle.<ref name=":0" /> The [[Gender Parity Index|gender parity index]] has revealed that more boys are enrolled in primary education (GPI=0.97) but more girls are enrolled in secondary (GPI=1.08) and tertiary education (GPI=1.54).<ref name=":3" /> Parents are more inclined to send young girls to school in order to secure their futures whereas young boys are more likely to inherit family property by surviving in harsh working conditions.<ref name=":1" />
=== Urban verses Rural === Multiple disparities exist between educational attainment in rural and urban settings.<ref name=":4" /> In rural areas, 6.4% of youth receive no education, which is three times higher compared to urban youth. The transition to a market system is the cause of higher illiteracy and drop out rates because many poor, rural households experienced economic hardships after the closure of cooperative farms.<ref name=":8" />
Regional constraints affect the availability of education, most commonly in rural areas. Statistical analysis has found a high correlation rate between parents and children’s educational attainment.<ref name=":9" /> [[Human capital]] gained and transferred from the educational level of parents is directly correlated with that of their children.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":9" /> Youth with vast human capital are able to move to larger aimag centers to continue their studies. Most higher secondary education and colleges are only available in large city’s like Mongolia’s capital Ulaanbaatar.
== Labor and employment == [[File:Mongolia Herding Life 11.JPG|thumb|Rural young men tend to their horses before herding cattle.]] Under the Labor Law and the Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor, Mongolian youth can legally work when they are 15 years old with parental permission, and those aged 14 can begin vocational training and employment.<ref name=":4" /> Labor codes dictate that the working week is 40 hours and 36 hours for those under 18.
Culturally appropriate jobs are rarely found by Mongolian youth, which translates into high youth unemployment rates in urban areas and very low productivity in rural areas. Private sector growth has been slow after the transition to capitalism, which has increased youth unemployment in urban areas and consequently many households resort to youth leaving school and taking employment in the agricultural sector.<ref name=":3" />
The 2006 School-to-Work Transition Survey revealed that of the youth surveyed 22.8% were unemployed and were registered with the employment office. In the same survey 66.1% of youth were employed as unpaid family workers, 23.9% had paid work and 8.3% were self-employed, 0.9% had a part-time job and 0.9% were employed but absent from work.<ref name=":4" /> Only one out of two jobs are wage paying jobs and are more commonly held by urban youth. Young women are more likely to be self-employed in urban areas, whereas young men are more frequently self-employed in rural locations. Gender gaps in employment opportunities are present, in which young men have a higher unemployment rate compared to female counterparts. Women at younger ages have lower unemployment rates due to higher educational attainment, and consequently higher rates of long-term unemployment.<ref name=":1" />
Academic training is preferred over technical education and vocational skills which has resulted in unfilled positions in trades. In total, unemployment rates were 15.3% lower for youth with vocational degrees compared to 11.6% of youth with tertiary degrees.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url = http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/mongolia_nhdr-2007-eng.pdf|title = Employment and Poverty in Mongolia|date = 2007|accessdate = October 22, 2015|website = |publisher = United Nations Development Programme|last = |first = }}</ref> Underage employment is common in rural communities particularly in the herding and mining sectors. Underage urban youth may work in poor working conditions generally in informal markets such as manufacturing. In 2009 56,000 5-17 year olds were engaged in child labor, 43,000 were below the minimum working age of 15 and 13,000 15-17 year olds were involved in hazardous work.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url = http://www.ucw-project.org/attachment/child_labour_youth_employment_Mongolia20110627_163644.pdf|title = Understanding children's work and youth employment outcomes in Mongolia|date = July 2009|accessdate = October 22, 2015|website = |publisher = Understanding Children's Work|last = Aldobrandini|first = Villa}}</ref>
== Health == Issues related to sexual and reproductive health, tobacco and alcohol usage, infectious disease and environmental related health issues are major concerns for Mongolian youth.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":12" /> All medical and hospital services are free and health care is under the control of state.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" />
The [[World Health Organization]] established and supports nine adolescent-friendly clinics around Mongolia. The clinic staff is trained on the adolescent orientation package which promotes preventive messages on psychosocial, nutritional, diseases prevention and sexual aspects of health. Although the clinics were youth friendly, the clinics lacked space, were not easy to reach, and were not open during convenient times for youth to access.<ref name=":4" /> The WHO 2002 reports show that 34% of youth surveyed were afraid that the health services received at these clinics were inadequate, 57.3% of the same youth surveyed reported that health care workers were inattentive to their health concerns and problems as well as giving poor services.<ref name=":4" />
=== Sexual and Reproductive Health === The 2008 Reproductive Health Survey revealed that 16.7% of 15-19 year olds surveyed responded that they had had sexual intercourse. 5.0% had their first sexual intercourse between 14 and 16 and 11.7% between the ages 17–19. This is in contrast to the Reproductive Health Survey of 2003, no adolescents reported having sexual intercourse for the first time between the ages of 11 and 13. The average age of first sexual intercourse for males was 16.8 and 18.9 for females.<ref name=":4" /> These results were similar for youth in both rural and urban areas.
The World Health Organization surveys found that youth's knowledge about contraceptives was high while use was low. Of the 1044 youth surveyed between the ages of 15 and 19 reported that 92.7% had knowledge of any modern method, 3.7% were currently using male condoms, IUDs and pills, and 33.5% knew that contraceptives were distributed without charge. The usage of contraceptives among females who reported having sexual intercourse during the month before the survey reported that 31.8% used condoms, 56.8% of those who were never married used condoms, and 39.7% of urban females used condoms compared to 16.7% of rural females.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" />
Legislation regarding youth sexual and reproductive health is prominent as seen by the Criminal Code of 2002 and the Health Act of 1998.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|title = Mongolia: Criminal Code of Mongolia|url = http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/text.jsp?file_id=183247|website = www.wipo.int|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref> Criminal Code of 2002 states that sexual intercourse with a minor under the age of 16 is punishable and abortion in nonmedical conditions or abortion by a nonprofessional is punishable. According to the Health Act of 1998 "abortion performed only in medical conditions that meet requirements and by licensed medical specialists as specified in the Law" are permitable.<ref name=":11" />
=== Tobacco and Alcohol === The 2010 Global School based Student Health Survey report found that 82.9% of males and 70.5% of females students age 13-15 had smoked cigarettes before the age of 14. 64.2% of those sampled in the same survey had been exposed to [[second-hand smoke]] at home. Of current youth smokers, 86.5% wanted to stop smoking while 65.3% of these same youth had received help to do so. The same survey found that 80% of youth agreed that smoking should be banned from public places. Under the new Tobacco Law of 2005, adolescents are forbidden from buying and selling tobacco. Legislation governing alcohol was amended in 2000, banning the sale of alcohol to minors under the age of 21.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.smoke-free.ca/warnings/warningsimages/mongolia/Mongolia-Tobacco%20Control%20Law_eng-2005.pdf|title = LAW ON TOBACCO CONTROL|date = July 1, 2005|accessdate = November 18, 2015|website = Physicians for a Smoke-Free Canada|publisher =Chairman of the [[State Great Hural of Mongolia]], Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia|last = Nyamdorj|first = TS. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525234449/http://www.smoke-free.ca/warnings/warningsimages/mongolia/Mongolia-Tobacco%20Control%20Law_eng-2005.pdf | archivedate= May 25, 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The 2005 Global School based Student Health survey and the 2000 Adolescents' Needs Assessment Survey reported 15-19 year olds had the highest mean alcohol consumption wherein urban adolescents drank twice as much alcohol as rural adolescents.<ref name=":12">{{cite book | chapterurl=http://countrystudies.us/mongolia/48.htm | title=Mongolia: A Country Study|chapter= Mongolia - Health and Welfare | publisher=[[United States Government Publishing Office|GPO]] for the [[Library of Congress]] | year=1989 | location=Washington | editors=Robert L. Worden and Andrea Matles Savada | series=[[A Country Study]]}}</ref> The 2010 Global School based Student Health Survey revealed that 79.4% of youth had consumed alcohol once a month or less. Of the respondents aged 15–19, 70.8% of males and 86.7% of females had not drunk in the last year, which had dropped significantly since the 2005 report.<ref name=":4" />
=== Infectious Disease === The World Health Organization has classified Mongolia as a low-prevalence STI country, yet the risk environment is increasing. Roughly half of the population is under the age of 23, which makes sexually active youth the most vulnerable population.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /> The United Nations Volunteer program, STI & HIV/AIDS Prevention among Vulnerable Groups in Mongolia 2007-2009, reports that prevention and awareness methods were not tailored to target sexually active youth. The main goal of this project was to reduce [[risky sexual behavior]] and develop programs that address issues of prevention for youth.<ref>{{Cite web|title = UN Volunteers Mongolia|url = http://www.un-mongolia.mn/unv/unvm_unvpm.html|website = www.un-mongolia.mn|accessdate = 2015-11-08}}</ref> The 2010 United Nations General Assembly Special Session reports found that over half of the adolescents reported that they felt that they did not have any risk of contracting HIV and one fourth considered themselves to be at low risk.
=== Environmental Health === The Systematic Review of the Impact of the Environment on Health in Mongolia revealed that poor environmental management and behaviors have increased Mongolian children's exposure to environmental risk factors and adverse health outcomes. The results from the study indicate that respiratory diseases and neurodevelopment disorders among youth are common due to significant exposure to outdoor and indoor air pollution, metals, tobacco smoke and other chemical toxins.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Impact of the Environment on Health in Mongolia A Systematic Review|url = http://aph.sagepub.com/content/27/1/45|journal = [[Asia-Pacific Journal of Public Health]]|date = 2015-01-01|issn = 1010-5395|pmid = 25113526|pages = 45–75|volume = 27|issue = 1|doi = 10.1177/1010539514545648|first = Amarzaya|last = Jadambaa|first2 = Jeffery|last2 = Spickett|first3 = Burmaajav|last3 = Badrakh|first4 = Rosana E.|last4 = Norman}}</ref>
== Ethnicity == Mongolia has been ruled by various [[Nomadic Empires of Central Asia|nomadic empires]], the [[Qing dynasty]] and the [[Soviet Union]]. The blending of many cultures has influenced youth identities with their ethnicities and traditional nomadic lifestyles. The transition to a [[market economy]] has brought about rapid [[urbanization]] and a change in modern-day youth identities.<ref>{{Cite web|title = When Nomads Settle The City: The Urbanization Of Mongolia|url = http://www.worldcrunch.com/culture-society/when-nomads-settle-the-city-the-urbanization-of-mongolia/mongolia-quot-ulan-bator-quot-urbanization-city-nomad-traffic-planning-yurt-desertification-pasture-herd/c3s9301/|website = worldcrunch.com|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTEAPREGTOPURBDEV/Resources/Mongolia-Urbanisation.pdf|title = Urbanization Dynamics and Policy Frameworks in Developing East Asia|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = The World Bank|last = |first = }}</ref><ref name=":13" />
[[Demographics of Mongolia|Mongolia's demographics]] reveal that Mongol groups make up approximately 95% of the population. There are over 20 different subgroupings of Mongol ethnicities and tribal affilications.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|title = Mongolian Ethnic - Unique type of nation|url = https://www.discovermongolia.mn/blog-news-mongolia-ethnic/|website = Welcome|accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref> The largest ethnic group is composed of [[Khalkha]], [[Buryats]] and [[Oirats]] Mongols. After the dissolution of Soviet control, nearly half of [[Mongolian Kazakhs]] youth and their families left Mongolia to find new sources of economic livelihood.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|title = Immobility and the re-imaginings of ethnic identity among Mongolian Kazakhs in the 21st century|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0016718514002735|journal = [[Geoforum]]|date = 2015-02-01|pages = 119–128|volume = 59|doi = 10.1016/j.geoforum.2014.12.007|first = Holly R.|last = Barcus|first2 = Cynthia|last2 = Werner|hdl = 1969.1/154303}}</ref> Many of these youth were traditional livestock herders and were expected to conform to gender roles; the move to Kazakhstan proved to be dismal and by 2000 over one third that migrated came back to Mongolia.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = History of Mongolia|url = http://mongolianembassy.us/about-mongolia/history/#.ViasZH6rTIU|website = Embassy of Mongolia|accessdate = 2015-10-21|language = English|date = 2013-05-21}}</ref>
Steven Harrell's book, ''Cultural Encounters on China's Ethnic Frontiers'', reveals identification with Mongol heritage differs for rural and urban youth. Pastoral rural Mongol youth identify their nomadic way of life was a basic foundation of Mongolian identity. Boundaries between non-monogols and the Han were created by rural youth through identification with the [[Mongolian language]]. Urban youth viewed and required ethnic education as a way to create a cultural space and to understand their common mythical history and family ties to the Mongolian population as a whole.<ref name=":13">{{Cite book|title = Cultural Encounters on China's Ethnic Frontier|last = Harrell|first = Steven|publisher = University of Washington Press|year = 1996|isbn = 978-0295975283|location = |pages = 290–300}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
